name: NOAA 15
description: Launched in 1998, this veteran weather satellite continues to deliver valuable atmospheric data after more than 25 years in orbit. NOAA 15's impressive longevity has provided meteorologists with a consistent long-term dataset, making it a cornerstone for climate change research while still contributing to daily weather forecasting worldwide.

name: DMSP 5D-3 F16 (USA 172)
description: Launched in 2003, this military weather satellite exemplifies the crucial intersection of defense and meteorology. F16's specialized sensors provide vital cloud cover and precipitation data to military planners while simultaneously contributing to civilian weather models, demonstrating how national security and public safety concerns can be addressed by the same space asset.

name: NOAA 18
description: Launched in 2005, this reliable weather sentinel has been tracking storms and monitoring environmental changes for nearly two decades. NOAA 18's suite of advanced instruments captures detailed images and atmospheric profiles used for hurricane tracking, sea ice monitoring, and climate studies, providing critical data that helps meteorologists protect lives and property worldwide.

name: METEOSAT-9 (MSG-2)
description: Launched in 2005, this European weather watchkeeper maintains a constant vigil over Africa, Europe, and the Middle East from its geostationary perch. MSG-2's rapid-scan capabilities capture the birth and evolution of severe weather systems every 15 minutes, providing crucial early warnings for dangerous storms while contributing to our understanding of regional climate patterns.

name: EWS-G1 (GOES 13)
description: Launched in 2006, this atmospheric sentinel began life as a civilian GOES satellite before being repurposed for military weather monitoring. After faithfully serving NOAA for years tracking hurricanes and severe storms over the Americas, it now continues its mission under a new designation, exemplifying how valuable weather satellites can find new purposes rather than face retirement.

name: DMSP 5D-3 F17 (USA 191)
description: Launched in 2006, this military weather observer combines national security with environmental monitoring in one sophisticated package. F17's microwave imaging and sounding suite can peer through clouds to detect precipitation patterns and sea ice extent, providing tactical weather intelligence to military operations while contributing valuable data to climate researchers studying polar ice changes.

name: FENGYUN 3A
description: Launched in 2008, this pioneering Chinese meteorological satellite marked a significant advancement in the country's weather observation capabilities. FY-3A's diverse array of 11 instruments measures everything from atmospheric temperature profiles to soil moisture, representing China's growing contribution to global weather forecasting networks while supporting the nation's ambitious disaster monitoring and prevention programs.

name: NOAA 19
description: Launched in 2009, this final member of NOAA's legendary POES satellite series caps a weather monitoring legacy stretching back to 1978. NOAA 19's comprehensive instrument suite continues to deliver detailed atmospheric soundings and imagery that support weather forecasting worldwide, while also monitoring ozone depletion and space weather events that can impact our technology-dependent civilization.

name: GOES 14
description: Launched in 2009, this vigilant weather sentinel patiently serves as an orbital backup, ready to spring into action when other satellites need maintenance or replacement. GOES 14's standby status exemplifies the redundancy built into critical weather monitoring infrastructure, ensuring continuous coverage of severe weather phenomena that could threaten lives and property across the Americas.

name: DMSP 5D-3 F18 (USA 210)
description: Launched in 2009, this military meteorological observer represents a critical link in the chain of weather satellites supporting national defense. F18's specialized sensors provide visibility through darkness and cloud cover, enabling military planners to anticipate weather conditions that might affect operations, while simultaneously contributing valuable data to global environmental monitoring and climate research efforts.

name: EWS-G2 (GOES 15)
description: Launched in 2010, this adaptable weather satellite exemplifies how space assets can find new purposes throughout their operational lives. After years of dedicated service to NOAA monitoring weather patterns over the western United States and Pacific Ocean, GOES 15 has transitioned to supporting military weather forecasting, extending its valuable contribution to both civilian safety and national security missions.

name: COMS 1
description: Launched in 2010, this multifunctional South Korean satellite represented a significant advancement in the nation's space capabilities. COMS 1's three-in-one design combined weather monitoring, ocean observation, and experimental communications technology in a single platform, demonstrating how smaller space-faring nations can maximize the efficiency of their satellite programs while contributing to regional weather forecasting.

name: FENGYUN 3B
description: Launched in 2010, this sophisticated Chinese weather satellite further expanded the country's growing meteorological monitoring capabilities. FY-3B's afternoon orbit complements its morning-orbit siblings, ensuring comprehensive daily coverage of atmospheric conditions, while its advanced instruments provide crucial data for weather forecasting, climate research, and environmental monitoring across Asia and beyond.

name: SUOMI NPP
description: Launched in 2011, this groundbreaking satellite represented a crucial bridge between generations of weather monitoring technology. Named for meteorology pioneer Verner Suomi, NPP introduced advanced instruments that dramatically improved weather forecasting precision while ensuring continuity of climate data records during a transition period between satellite series, demonstrating forward-thinking program management in Earth observation.

name: METEOSAT-10 (MSG-3)
description: Launched in 2012, this vigilant European weather sentinel maintains a constant watch over Africa, Europe, and neighboring oceans from its geostationary vantage point. MSG-3's rapid-scan imagery captures the formation and movement of weather systems every 15 minutes, providing crucial early warnings for severe storms while supporting numerical weather prediction models that have revolutionized forecasting accuracy across multiple continents.

name: METOP-B
description: Launched in 2012, this European polar orbiter represents a cornerstone of the global atmospheric monitoring network. METOP-B's sophisticated suite of instruments provides crucial vertical profiles of temperature and humidity that dramatically improve the accuracy of numerical weather prediction models, while simultaneously tracking ozone levels, monitoring solar radiation, and even relaying distress signals from ships and aircraft in trouble.

name: INSAT-3D
description: Launched in 2013, this Indian meteorological powerhouse significantly enhanced weather forecasting capabilities across the subcontinent. INSAT-3D's advanced imager and sounder instruments provide crucial real-time data on developing monsoons, cyclones, and other weather phenomena affecting more than a billion people, while its data relay transponder connects automated weather stations across remote regions, creating a comprehensive monitoring network.

name: FENGYUN 3C
description: Launched in 2013, this advanced Chinese meteorological satellite further expanded the nation's weather monitoring capabilities with next-generation technology. FY-3C's suite of 12 sophisticated instruments includes microwave sounders that can peer through clouds to measure atmospheric conditions below, significantly enhancing precipitation forecasts while contributing to China's growing role in international meteorological cooperation.

name: METEOR-M 2
description: Launched in 2014, this Russian weather monitoring satellite significantly enhanced the nation's meteorological capabilities with its modern sensor suite. Meteor-M 2's combination of visible, infrared, and microwave instruments provides comprehensive data on atmospheric conditions, sea surface temperatures, and ice coverage, supporting accurate forecasting across Russia's vast territory while contributing valuable polar observations to the international weather monitoring community.

name: HIMAWARI-8
description: Launched in 2014, this Japanese meteorological marvel revolutionized weather observation across the Asia-Pacific region with unprecedented imaging capabilities. Himawari-8's advanced imager captures full-disk Earth images every 10 minutes with exceptional resolution and 16 spectral bands, providing stunning visual clarity of typhoons, volcanic eruptions, and other environmental phenomena while dramatically improving forecast accuracy for countries across a third of the globe.

name: FENGYUN 2G
description: Launched in 2014, this Chinese geostationary satellite continued the expansion of the nation's weather monitoring capabilities with enhanced regional coverage. FY-2G's strategic positioning over the Indian Ocean extended China's meteorological reach westward, providing crucial data on weather systems developing over this vital region while supporting the Belt and Road Initiative by offering improved weather services to partner nations across Asia and Africa.

name: METEOSAT-11 (MSG-4)
description: Launched in 2015, this European weather watchkeeper represents the culmination of second-generation Meteosat technology after decades of refinement. MSG-4's position over the prime meridian provides crucial coverage of Europe, Africa, and surrounding oceans with 12-channel multispectral imagery every 15 minutes, supporting everything from immediate severe weather warnings to long-term climate studies of this environmentally diverse and populous region.

name: ELEKTRO-L 2
description: Launched in 2015, this Russian geostationary weather sentinel expanded the nation's monitoring capabilities with its strategic positioning over the Indian Ocean. Elektro-L 2's multispectral imager captures the full Earth disk every 30 minutes, providing crucial data on weather systems affecting Russia and neighboring regions while completing a global network that ensures comprehensive coverage of our planet's dynamic atmospheric conditions.

name: INSAT-3DR
description: Launched in 2016, this Indian meteorological satellite expanded the nation's weather monitoring capabilities with advanced imaging and atmospheric sounding. INSAT-3DR's diverse instrument package tracks monsoon developments, tropical cyclones, and severe thunderstorms with greater precision, while its specialized Search and Rescue transponder has helped locate and rescue people in distress, making it both a weather forecasting asset and a lifesaving tool.

name: HIMAWARI-9
description: Launched in 2016, this Japanese weather sentinel serves as a critical backup to its twin Himawari-8, ensuring continuous coverage of the Asia-Pacific region. Himawari-9's standby status exemplifies the redundancy built into essential weather monitoring infrastructure, ready to maintain the flow of high-resolution, multi-spectral imagery that protects millions of people from typhoons and other severe weather threats across this densely populated region.

name: GOES 16
description: Launched in 2016, this revolutionary American weather satellite represented a quantum leap in capabilities over its predecessors. GOES-16's advanced imager captures breathtaking full-disk Earth images every 10 minutes at four times the resolution and five times faster than previous technology, while its Geostationary Lightning Mapper tracks lightning strikes in real-time, revolutionizing severe storm prediction and giving forecasters unprecedented tools to protect lives and property.

name: FENGYUN 4A
description: Launched in 2016, this pioneering Chinese satellite inaugurated a new generation of geostationary weather monitoring capabilities. FY-4A's advanced instruments, including the first Chinese geostationary hyperspectral infrared sounder, have dramatically improved the nation's ability to detect and track severe weather phenomena, representing China's growing technological sophistication in space-based Earth observation and meteorological forecasting.

name: CYGFM05
description: Launched in 2016, this innovative microsatellite is part of a constellation that revolutionized tropical cyclone forecasting with a novel approach. CYGFM05's specialized GPS receiver measures signals reflected off the ocean surface, allowing scientists to determine wind speeds within hurricanes and typhoons even when cloud cover blocks traditional satellite views, dramatically improving intensity forecasts for these dangerous storms.

name: NOAA 20 (JPSS-1)
description: Launched in 2017, this sophisticated polar-orbiting satellite represents the new generation of American weather monitoring technology. NOAA 20's suite of advanced instruments provides unprecedented detail of atmospheric conditions, sea surface temperatures, and polar ice, delivering critical data that has improved weather forecast accuracy by 50% while tracking environmental changes like Arctic ice loss with remarkable precision.

name: CYGFM08
description: Launched in 2016 as part of an innovative constellation, this microsatellite helped revolutionize tropical cyclone forecasting with creative technology. CYGFM08's ability to measure ocean surface roughness by detecting reflected GPS signals allows meteorologists to determine hurricane wind speeds in regions where traditional aircraft reconnaissance is unavailable, significantly improving intensity predictions for these dangerous storms.

name: CYGFM07
description: Launched in 2016 as part of the CYGNSS constellation, this compact weather observer exemplifies how small satellites can solve big problems. CYGFM07's innovative use of reflected GPS signals to measure wind speeds over oceans has dramatically improved tropical cyclone intensity forecasting, demonstrating how creative engineering approaches can provide crucial data that larger, more expensive satellites miss, especially in the dangerous eyewalls of hurricanes.

name: CYGFM03
description: Launched in 2016 as part of a groundbreaking constellation, this microsatellite demonstrates how innovative thinking can solve stubborn meteorological challenges. CYGFM03's ability to peer through the heavy precipitation of tropical cyclones using reflected GPS signals provides crucial wind data in regions where conventional instruments fail, helping forecasters better predict the strength and development of these dangerous storm systems.

name: FENGYUN 3D
description: Launched in 2017, this advanced Chinese polar-orbiting satellite continues the expansion of the nation's impressive meteorological monitoring capabilities. FY-3D's morning orbit complements afternoon-orbit siblings to provide comprehensive daily coverage, while its cutting-edge instruments support more accurate weather forecasting, environmental monitoring, and climate research, emphasizing China's growing role in international Earth observation cooperation.

name: GOES 17
description: Launched in 2018, this sophisticated American weather sentinel maintains a vigilant watch over the western United States and Pacific Ocean. Despite early cooling system challenges that showcased the resilience of aerospace engineering, GOES-17's advanced instruments provide detailed monitoring of wildfires, atmospheric rivers, volcanic eruptions, and other phenomena affecting the western hemisphere, dramatically improving forecast accuracy and emergency response capabilities.

name: FENGYUN 2H
description: Launched in 2018, this Chinese geostationary satellite represents the culmination of the FY-2 series after decades of meteorological mission development. FY-2H's strategic positioning over the Indian Ocean provides crucial coverage of weather patterns affecting Asia and eastern Africa, supporting China's expanding international partnerships while detecting tropical cyclones, monitoring monsoon development, and tracking dust storms across this environmentally dynamic region.

name: METOP-C
description: Launched in 2018, this European polar-orbiting satellite completed a constellation that has revolutionized global weather forecasting accuracy. MetOp-C's sophisticated instrument suite provides detailed profiles of atmospheric temperature and humidity, tracks atmospheric composition, and monitors sea ice extent, contributing essential data to numerical weather prediction models that have dramatically improved forecast reliability from days to weeks ahead.

name: GEO-KOMPSAT-2A
description: Launched in 2018, this sophisticated South Korean satellite represented a major advancement in the nation's meteorological capabilities. GEO-KOMPSAT-2A's advanced imager provides 16 spectral bands of high-resolution imagery covering the Asia-Pacific region every 10 minutes, supporting more accurate forecasting of typhoons, heavy rainfall, and other severe weather events while monitoring air quality, sea surface temperatures, and other environmental parameters vital to South Korea's security and economy.

name: METEOR-M2 2
description: Launched in 2019, this Russian polar-orbiting satellite expanded the nation's weather monitoring capabilities despite early challenges that tested ground controllers' ingenuity. Meteor-M2-2's diverse sensor suite provides comprehensive data on atmospheric conditions, sea surface temperatures, and ice coverage even after surviving a micrometeoroid strike, demonstrating the resilience of modern satellite design while delivering valuable environmental information across Russia's vast and climatically diverse territory.

name: ARKTIKA-M 1
description: Launched in 2021, this pioneering Russian satellite introduced a revolutionary approach to monitoring Earth's polar regions. Arktika-M1's highly elliptical orbit provides persistent coverage of the Arctic with regular 15-30 minute imagery, filling a crucial gap left by geostationary satellites that cannot effectively observe high latitudes, enabling better monitoring of rapidly changing Arctic weather patterns, sea ice dynamics, and climate change impacts.

name: FENGYUN 3E
description: Launched in 2021, this advanced Chinese meteorological satellite introduced innovative early-morning orbit monitoring to the global weather observation system. FY-3E's dawn-monitoring capability complements existing morning and afternoon orbiters, creating more comprehensive daily coverage of evolving weather systems while its cutting-edge instruments measure everything from atmospheric temperature profiles to soil moisture, enhancing China's contribution to international weather forecasting efforts.

name: GOES 18
description: Launched in 2022, this advanced American weather sentinel maintains vigilant watch over the western United States and Pacific Ocean with state-of-the-art capabilities. GOES-18's enhanced imaging system captures detailed views of wildfires, atmospheric rivers, and tropical cyclones, while its Geostationary Lightning Mapper tracks lightning strikes in real-time, providing forecasters with unprecedented tools to predict severe weather development and protect lives and property across the western hemisphere.

name: NOAA 21 (JPSS-2)
description: Launched in 2022, this sophisticated American polar-orbiting satellite continues the modernization of global weather monitoring capabilities. NOAA 21's advanced instruments provide unprecedented detail of atmospheric conditions, ocean temperatures, and environmental changes with remarkable accuracy, delivering critical data that supports everything from next-day weather forecasts to long-term climate research, while helping meteorologists predict extreme events that threaten lives and property worldwide.

name: METEOSAT-12 (MTG-I1)
description: Launched in 2022, this revolutionary European satellite inaugurated a new generation of weather monitoring capabilities after years of development. MTG-I1's Lightning Imager represents the first operational lightning detection system from geostationary orbit over Europe and Africa, while its 16-channel high-resolution imager captures atmospheric developments every 10 minutes, providing unprecedented tools for detecting and tracking severe storms that threaten lives and property.

name: TIANMU-1 03
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite forms part of an ambitious constellation focused on real-time tracking and forecasting of tropical cyclones and severe weather. Tianmu-1 03's compact size belies its sophisticated capabilities, with specialized instruments designed to measure atmospheric temperature, humidity, and precipitation, demonstrating China's growing expertise in developing coordinated small satellite networks that complement traditional larger weather monitoring platforms.

name: TIANMU-1 04
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite exemplifies a modern trend toward using coordinated satellite constellations to enhance weather monitoring capabilities. Tianmu-1 04's specialized instruments work in concert with its constellation partners to provide comprehensive, frequent observations of developing weather systems, particularly focusing on the rapid changes that occur during tropical cyclone formation and intensification across the western Pacific region.

name: TIANMU-1 05
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite contributes to an innovative weather monitoring network designed to track and forecast severe weather events. Tianmu-1 05's coordinated operations with its constellation partners enable more frequent observations than possible with single satellites, providing crucial data on rapidly developing storm systems and enhancing China's ability to predict and respond to dangerous weather phenomena threatening densely populated coastal regions.

name: TIANMU-1 06
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite forms part of a sophisticated constellation focused on monitoring and forecasting severe weather events. Tianmu-1 06's combination of compact size and advanced sensors demonstrates a growing trend toward distributed weather monitoring systems, where multiple smaller satellites work in coordination to provide more frequent coverage than possible with individual larger platforms, enhancing prediction capabilities for dangerous storms.

name: METEOR-M2 3
description: Launched in 2023, this advanced Russian meteorological satellite expanded the nation's weather monitoring capabilities with next-generation technology. Meteor-M2-3's diverse sensor suite provides comprehensive data on atmospheric conditions, sea surface temperatures, and ice coverage across Russia's vast territory, from the Baltic to the Pacific, enhancing forecast accuracy while contributing valuable observations of the rapidly changing Arctic region to the international meteorological community.

name: TIANMU-1 07
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite extends the innovative Tianmu constellation's capabilities for monitoring severe weather systems. Tianmu-1 07's specialized instruments work in coordination with its constellation partners to track rapidly evolving tropical cyclones and monsoon developments, demonstrating China's commitment to enhancing its meteorological capabilities through modern distributed satellite networks that provide more frequent observations than traditional single-satellite approaches.

name: TIANMU-1 08
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite contributes to an expanding constellation focused on enhancing severe weather prediction capabilities. Tianmu-1 08's coordination with its constellation partners enables more frequent observations of developing weather systems than possible with individual larger satellites, providing crucial data for meteorologists tracking typhoons, heavy rainfall events, and other dangerous weather phenomena affecting China's densely populated coastal regions.

name: TIANMU-1 09
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite extends an innovative constellation approach to weather monitoring and prediction. Tianmu-1 09's compact yet sophisticated instruments work in concert with multiple constellation partners to provide frequent observations of developing weather systems, demonstrating how modern distributed satellite networks can enhance forecasting capabilities by capturing the rapid changes that occur during storm development and intensification.

name: TIANMU-1 10
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite forms part of a cutting-edge constellation focused on improving severe weather forecasting capabilities. Tianmu-1 10's collaboration with its constellation partners enables meteorologists to track rapidly evolving storm systems with greater frequency than possible with traditional satellite approaches, enhancing China's ability to predict and respond to dangerous weather phenomena that threaten lives and infrastructure.

name: FENGYUN 3F
description: Launched in 2023, this advanced Chinese polar-orbiting satellite continued the evolution of the nation's meteorological monitoring capabilities. FY-3F's sophisticated instrument suite provides comprehensive data on atmospheric temperature profiles, precipitation patterns, and environmental parameters, enhancing China's contribution to the global weather forecasting network while supporting climate research and disaster monitoring efforts across Asia and beyond.

name: ARKTIKA-M 2
description: Launched in 2023, this innovative Russian satellite expanded an unprecedented approach to monitoring Earth's rapidly changing polar regions. Arktika-M2's highly elliptical orbit complements its sister satellite by providing alternating coverage of the Arctic, ensuring continuous observation of this climatically crucial region with 15-30 minute imagery, filling the observation gap left by traditional geostationary satellites that cannot effectively monitor high latitudes.

name: TIANMU-1 11
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite extends the ambitious Tianmu constellation dedicated to enhanced monitoring of severe weather systems. Tianmu-1 11's compact yet sophisticated instruments work in coordination with numerous constellation partners to provide frequent observations of developing tropical cyclones, monsoon patterns, and other significant weather phenomena, demonstrating China's commitment to distributed satellite networks for improved meteorological forecasting.

name: TIANMU-1 12
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite contributes to an expanding constellation focused on enhancing weather forecasting precision through coordinated observations. Tianmu-1 12's specialized instruments complement its constellation partners by monitoring specific atmospheric parameters, demonstrating how modern distributed satellite networks can provide more frequent updates on developing weather systems than possible with traditional approaches, particularly for fast-evolving phenomena like tropical cyclones.

name: TIANMU-1 13
description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite extends the Tianmu constellation's capabilities for monitoring severe weather systems. Tianmu-1 13's compact yet sophisticated instruments work in coordination with its constellation partners to track rapidly evolving tropical cyclones, monsoon patterns, and other significant weather phenomena, demonstrating China's commitment to distributed satellite networks for improved meteorological forecasting.

description: Launched in 2023, this Chinese microsatellite contributes to the Tianmu constellation's innovative approach to weather monitoring and prediction. Tianmu-1 14's compact yet sophisticated instruments work in concert with its constellation partners to provide frequent observations of developing weather systems, demonstrating how modern distributed satellite networks can enhance forecasting capabilities by capturing the rapid changes that occur during storm development and intensification.

Tianmu-1 19's compact yet sophisticated instruments work in coordination with its constellation partners to track rapidly evolving tropical cyclones, monsoon patterns, and other significant weather phenomena, demonstrating China's commitment to distributed satellite networks for improved meteorological forecasting.
